p: The IRIS stage of CKD was determined according to IRIS guidelines, 15 where IRIS stage is assigned based on serum creatinine and SDMA concentrations and whether an abnormal kidney on palpation, dilute urine or elevated UPC ratio are present and persistent over a period of at least 3 months. Cats were considered to have early stage 1 CKD (non-azotemic) based on one or more of the following: serum creatinine increasing within the reference range (<1.6 mg/dl), persistently increased serum SDMA (>13.5 µg/dl) or persistent renal proteinuria (UPC >0.4). Cats were considered to have stage 2 CKD if both SDMA (>13.5 µg/dl) and serum creatinine (1.6–2.8 mg/dl) were elevated, and USG was <1.035.
